skill.name: chinese-learning-assistant
skill.summary: For HSK4-level learners seeking fluency. Analyzes Chinese expression usage and naturalness. Improves writing to sound like a native speaker.
skill.author: 0918nobita

security_audit.summary: Evaluated 5 files (2500 lines). Static findings are false positives: backtick patterns in markdown are documentation formatting and search query examples, not shell execution. No malicious code detected. Skill is a legitimate Chinese language learning tool with standard web search capability for finding authentic usage examples.

content.user_title: Improve Your Chinese Writing to Sound Native
content.value_statement: Intermediate Chinese learners struggle to express themselves naturally. This skill analyzes expressions for natural usage context and transforms textbook Chinese into fluent, native-like writing with real-world examples from authentic sources.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes Chinese expressions for formality level, spoken/written distinction, and appropriate audience
Finds real-world usage examples from platforms like bilibili and Weibo through web search
Improves Chinese writing to sound natural and native-like rather than textbook-style
Provides multiple expression alternatives with context-specific usage guidance
Supports essay, conversation, and chat message writing styles
Validates suggested expressions against authentic current usage
limitations: Designed for HSK4-level learners; may not suit complete beginners or advanced speakers
Does not teach grammar fundamentals; focuses on natural expression improvement
Cannot provide real-time conversation practice; analyzes submitted text only
Does not include audio pronunciation features

use_cases.title: Writing Natural Chat Messages
use_cases.description: Transform stiff, textbook-style messages into casual, natural Chinese that sounds authentic when chatting with Chinese friends on WeChat or other platforms.
use_cases.target_user: Chinese learners who communicate with native speakers online

use_cases.title: Understanding Online Content
use_cases.description: Analyze expressions seen in bilibili videos, Weibo posts, or Chinese social media to understand how natives actually use language in context.
use_cases.target_user: Learners who consume Chinese media content regularly

use_cases.title: Improving Essay Writing
use_cases.description: Elevate essay writing from academic textbook style to natural flowing prose with proper connectors and authentic expression choices.
use_cases.target_user: Students preparing for Chinese language proficiency exams

prompt_templates.title: Beginner: Simple Expression Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Please analyze this Chinese expression: [expression]. Tell me when and how native speakers use it. Provide 2-3 example sentences.
prompt_templates.scenario: Learning a new expression and wanting to understand its natural usage

prompt_templates.title: Intermediate: Writing Improvement
prompt_templates.prompt: Please improve this Chinese sentence to sound more natural: [sentence]. Explain why the original sounds unnatural and what makes the improved version better. Find real examples of the improved expression from bilibili or Weibo.
prompt_templates.scenario: Transforming textbook Chinese into natural, native-like expression

prompt_templates.title: Advanced: Full Essay Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this Chinese paragraph I wrote: [paragraph]. Identify areas where it sounds unnatural or too textbook-like. Provide improved versions with explanations of the natural alternatives. Include real examples showing how natives express the same ideas.
prompt_templates.scenario: Comprehensive review of longer writing pieces for fluency improvement

prompt_templates.title: Expert: Expression Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare these similar expressions: [expression1] vs [expression2]. When should I use each one? What nuances differ? Show me examples of both in authentic contexts from web search.
prompt_templates.scenario: Understanding subtle differences between similar expressions

best_practices: Provide the specific context and audience for your writing so the skill can choose the most appropriate expressions
Ask for real examples from web search when learning new expressions to see current authentic usage
Request multiple alternatives to understand the range of natural options available
anti_patterns: Asking for literal translations without context, which leads to unnatural textbook Chinese
Expecting grammar explanations; focus on this skill on natural expression over grammar rules
Submitting very long texts without specifying the intended purpose or audience

faq.question: What level of Chinese learner is this skill for?
faq.answer: This skill is designed for learners at approximately HSK4 level or above who already have basic grammar foundations and want to improve their expression naturalness.

faq.question: Does this skill teach grammar?
faq.answer: No, this skill focuses on expression naturalness and fluency. Grammar correction is secondary and only addresses obvious errors that affect comprehension.

faq.question: How does web search help with learning?
faq.answer: Web search finds real examples from bilibili, Weibo, and other Chinese platforms so you can see how expressions are actually used in context by native speakers.

faq.question: Can this skill help with speaking practice?
faq.answer: Not directly. The skill analyzes written text and provides examples. For speaking, use the improved expressions in conversation practice with native speakers.

faq.question: What types of writing can this skill help with?
faq.answer: The skill supports chat messages, social media posts, essays, emails, and general conversational writing in both formal and casual styles.

faq.question: How is this different from machine translation?
faq.answer: Unlike translation tools, this skill focuses on making already-composed Chinese sound natural and native-like rather than translating from other languages.
